facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1096 of 1970 is an appeal by certificate from the Gujarat High Court judgment and order dated October 3 and 4, 1968 in Estate Duty Tax Reference No. 1 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1096 of 1970. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated October3 and 4,.1968 of the Gujarat High Court at Ahmedabad in Estate Duty Tax Reference No. 1 of 1968.

facts.text: Bai Safiabai, widow of Eusufalli Badri, died on 6-10-1955.

anchor.surface_text: Herein we are companycerned with the estate of Bai Safiabai  the widow of Eusufalli Badri  who died on 6-10-1955. The High Court opined that only 1/3rd of the trust estate of which the deceased was one of the trustees passed on her death.

facts.text: Eusufalli Ebrahimji settled immovable properties and leasehold lands on trust by indenture dated 15-7-1938.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts of the case may number be stated, One Eusufalli Ebrahimji settled upon trust certain immovable properties and leasehold lands by an indenture date 15-7- 1938.

facts.text: Trustees appointed under the deed: Eusufalli the settlor, his wife Bai Safiabai, and their eldest son Mohamedbhai the accountable person.

anchor.surface_text: Under that deed three trustees were appointed. They were Eusufalli  the settlor , his wife Bai Safiabai  the deceased  and their eldest son Mohamedbhai, the accountable person.

facts.text: Under trust deed, settlor entitled to net income of trust properties during his lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the trust deed, the settlor was entitled to the net income of the trust properties during his life lime.

facts.text: After settlor's death, income divided into three equal shares: 1/3rd to Bai Safiabai during her lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: After his death, the income of those properties was to be divided into three equal shares 1/3rd of the income was to be appropriated by Bai Safiabai during her life time.

facts.text: Out of remaining 2/3rd income after settlor's death, 1/3rd to Mohamedbhai and 1/3rd to maintenance of two wives and children of settlor's youngest son Salebhai who died before trust deed.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the remaining 2/3rd, 1/3rd was to be paid to Mohomedbhai and the remaining 1/3rd was to be entrusted to Mohomedbhai for being utilised for The maintenance of the two wives and the children of the settlors youngest son Salebhai, who had died before the trust deed was executed.

facts.text: Salebhai, settlor's youngest son, died before the trust deed was executed.

anchor.surface_text: the settlors youngest son Salebhai, who had died before the trust deed was executed.

facts.text: After Safiabai's death, trustees to divide trust properties: one equal share (half) to eldest son Mohamedbhai or his children and wife per religion dictates; other half to Salebhai's wife and children with two anna share to each of two wives and remaining twelve annas to children per religion.

anchor.surface_text: The settlor prescribed in the trust deed that after the death ,of Safiabai The trustees divide the trust properties in such a manner that one equal share i.e. half share shall be given to my eldest son, Mohomedbhai, and if he has died before that then, that share shall be given to his children and wife and that division shall be made according to dictates of my religion and the other half share shall be given to the wife and children of Salebhai in such manner that the two anna share shall be given to each of his two wives and the remaining twelve annas shall be distributed amongst his  Salebhais  children according to the dictates of my religion and after doing so this trust shall companye to an end.

facts.text: Assistant Controller determined value of Safiabai's estate at Rs. 4,15,000/- consisting of her individual properties and 1/3rd of trust properties.

anchor.surface_text: Safiabai, as mentioned earlier, died on 6-10-1955. The value of the estate left by her was determined by the Assistant Controller at Rs. 4,15,000/-. According to the Assistant Controller the estate left by the deceased companysisted of two times  a  of her individual properties and  b  1/3rd of the trust properties.

facts.text: Accountable person objected to inclusion of 1/3rd share in trust properties in computation of Safiabai's estate value.

anchor.surface_text: The accountable person objected to the inclusion of the value of the 1/3rd share in the trust properties in the companyputation of the value of the estate that passed on the death of Safiabai.

facts.text: Assistant Controller overruled accountable person's objection to inclusion of 1/3rd trust share.

anchor.surface_text: But that objection was overruled by the Assistant Controller.

facts.text: Accountable person appealed to Appellate Controller.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by that decision, the accountable person went up in appeal to the Appellate Controller.

facts.text: Appellate Controller refused permission to accountable person to withdraw the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: But, later on the accountable person sought to withdraw the appeal. The Appellate Controller refused to him permission to withdraw the appeal.

facts.text: Appellate Controller issued notice to show cause why entire trust estate should not be included; rejected contention that trust property did not belong to deceased; included entire trust property and enhanced valuation by Rs. 5,73,000/-

anchor.surface_text: Further, he gave him numberice requiring him to show cause why the entire value of the trust estate should number be included in the companyputation of the value of the estate that passed on the death of Safiabai. The account- able person companytended that the trust property did number belong to the deceased and as such the same cannot be said to have passed on her death. That companytention was rejected and the entire trust property was companysidered as the property that passed on the death of the deceased. Consequently the valuation made by the Assistant Controller was enhanced by Rs. 5,73,000/-

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal set aside Appellate Controller's order and restored Assistant Controller's order holding only 1/3rd of trust estate passed on deceased's death.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the Appellate Controller, the accountable person went up in appeal to. the Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Controller and restored that of the Assistant Controller. It held that only 1/3rd of the trust estate Passed on the death of the deceased.

facts.text: At instance of Department, question referred to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter at the instance of the Department, the question set out earlier was submitted to the High Court seeking its opinion thereon.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court answered first question in favour of accountable person; held only beneficial interest (1/3rd) of deceased in trust estate passed on her death.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in favour of the accountable person, In view of that answer, it thought it unnecessary to answer the second question. ... The High Court opined that only 1/3rd of the trust estate of which the deceased was one of the trustees passed on her death.

facts.text: Department contends entire trust estate passed on death of deceased.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Department, the entire Trust estate passed on the death of the deceased.

facts.text: Accountable person contends only 1/3rd interest in trust property passed on deceased's death.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it was companytended on behalf of the accountable person that the deceased had only 1/3rd interest in the trust property and that alone passed on her death.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds only 1/3rd interest in trust property passed on Safiabai's death as that was her beneficial interest in income.

anchor.surface_text: In substance, only 1/3rd interest in the trust property passed on her death. ... The deceased Safiabai had only 1/3rd share in the income of the trust property. That interest undoubtedly passed on her death.

facts.text: Ever since settlor's death, beneficial interest in 2/3rd income of trust property vested in persons other than deceased.

anchor.surface_text: From the facts mentioned earlier, it is seen that ever since the death of the settlor, beneficial interest in 2/3rd of the income of the trust property vested on persons other than the deceased.

facts.text: Tribunal referred three questions partly at instance of Department and partly at instance of accountable person.

anchor.surface_text: Therein the Tribunal referred partly at the instance of the Department and, partly at the instance of the accountable person three questions of law said to arise from its order, for the decision of the High Court

in a Reference under S. 64 1  of the Estate Duty Act  to be hereinafter referred to as. the Act . Therein the Tribunal referred partly at the instance of the Department and, partly at the instance of the accountable person three questions of law said to arise from its order, for the decision of the High Court

anchor.surface_text: At this stage we may refer to ss. 2 15  and 2 16  of the Act. Section 2 15  says property includes any interest in property, movable, or immovable, the proceeds of sale thereof and any money or investment, for the time being representing the. proceeds of sale and also includes any property companyverted from on species into another by any method.

concepts.interpretation: Broad definition of property includes any interest in property

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 16  defines the expression property pass on the death. That provision runs thus property passing on the death includes property passing either immediately on the death or after any interval, either certainly or companytingently, and either originally or by way of substitutive limitation. and on the death includes that a period ascertainable only by reference to the death

concepts.interpretation: Inclusive definition; court holds it does not exhaust meaning, requires examination of beneficial change

The expression property passing on death is number a technical expression. In other words, it is number a term of law, The word passes means changes hands. In the remaining 2/3rd Income, she had numberinterest and the same did number pass on her death. Her title to the property as a trustee was purely I personal right. It had numbervalue in terms of money.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the whole of the Trust estate was to be included in the assessment or only a portion thereof and if so what portion

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the whole of the Trust estate was to be included in the assessment or only a portion thereof and if so what portion

issues.text: Whether the title to the trust properties vested in the trustees till the death of the deceased passed to the beneficiaries immediately the deceased died such that the entire trust property passed on the death of the deceased

anchor.surface_text: Before us it was contended on behalf of the Department that the title to the trust properties vested in the trustees till the death of the deceased. That title Passed to the beneficiaries imme- diately the deceased died. The title that passed on the death of the deceased was the title in respect of the entire trust property and therefore we must hold that the entire trust property passed on the death of the deceased.

issues.text: Whether the deceased had only 1/3rd interest in the trust property and that alone passed on her death and the deceased's position as a trustee which came to an end on her death can be considered as property passing on her death

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it was contended on behalf of the accountable person that the deceased had only 1/3rd interest in the trust property and that alone passed on her death. According to him, the deceaseds position as a trustee, which came to an end on her death cannot be considered as property passing on her death.

issues.text: What is the scope of s. 5 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: To decide the controversy between the parties, it is necessary to, find the scope of s. 5 1  of the Act.

arguments.claim: The title to the trust properties vested in the trustees till the death of the deceased and passed to the beneficiaries immediately after her death, so the entire trust property passed on her death and its value must be included in the estate duty computation

anchor.surface_text: Before us it was contended on behalf of the Department that the title to the trust properties vested in the trustees till the death of the deceased. That title Passed to the beneficiaries imme- diately the deceased died. The title that passed on the death of the deceased was the title in respect of the entire trust property and therefore we must hold that the entire trust property passed on the death of the deceased. Hence, the value of the entire trust property should be taken into consideration in computing the value of the estate that passed on the death of the deceased.

arguments.court_reasoning: Passing requires change in beneficial interest, not mere legal title; trustee's title has no monetary value and only imposes duties

arguments.claim: The deceased had only 1/3rd interest in the trust property which alone passed on her death, and her position as trustee ending on death cannot be considered property passing on death

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it was contended on behalf of the accountable person that the deceased had only 1/3rd interest in the trust property and that alone passed on her death. According to him, the deceaseds position as a trustee, which came to an end on her death cannot be considered as property passing on her death.

arguments.court_reasoning: Deceased entitled only to 1/3rd income share which passed; no interest in 2/3rd; trustee title not property

arguments.claim: Under s.5 of the Act, estate duty is levied only on property which passes on the death of the deceased

anchor.surface_text: To decide the controversy between the parties, it is necessary to, find the scope of s. 5 1  of the Act. That section reads In the case of every person dying after the commencement of this Act. there shall, save as hereinafter expressly provided, be levied and paid upon the principal value ascertained as hereinafter provided of all property, settled or not settled, including agricultural land situate in the territories which immediately before the 1st November, 1956, were comprised in the States specified in the First Schedule, to this Act, which passes on the death of such person, a duty called estate duty at the rates fixed in accordance with Section 35.

arguments.claim: Section 2(16) provides an inclusive definition of 'property passing on the death' but does not exhaust its meaning; it requires a comparison of beneficial interests before and after death to determine if property passes

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 16  defines the expression property pass on the death. That provision runs thus property passing on the death includes property passing either immediately on the death or after any interval, either certainly or contingently, and either originally or by way of substitutive limitation. and on the death includes that a period ascertainable only by reference to the death This definition is only an inclusive definition. It does not bring out the meaning of the expression property passing on the death. The expression property passing on death is not a technical expression. In other words, it is not a term of law, The word passes means changes hands. To ascertain whether property has passed, a comparison must be made between the persons beneficially interested the moment before the death and the persons so interested the moment after the death-see the observations of Lord Russell of Killowen in Scott and Coutts and Co. v. Inland Revenue Commissioner 1 .

arguments.claim: If beneficial enjoyment is unaffected by death, property does not pass even if legal limitations change

anchor.surface_text: It is observed in Greens Death Duties at p. 34 If. after much a comparison, it appears that the beneficial enjoyment of the property  a definable part thereof  was, in substance and in events, unaffected by the death, the property  or that part thereof  did not pass on the death merely because, as a matter of terminology, one set of limitations then ceased to have effect and another became operatives. It is further observed therein to the extent that there is no change or beneficial enjoyment de facto, property does not pass merely because the exact nature or extent of the beneficial interests after the death was not ascertainable until that event occurred or because the beneficiary was entitled to income only before the death and to capital thereafter.

arguments.claim: Ever since the settlor's death, beneficial interest in 2/3rd income vested in others; deceased had only 1/3rd income interest which passed on her death

anchor.surface_text: From the facts mentioned earlier, it is seen that ever since the death of the settlor, beneficial interest in 2/3rd of the income of the trust property vested on persons other than the deceased. The deceased was entitled only to on 1/3rd share in the income of the trust property. In substance, only 1/3rd interest in the trust property passed on her death.

arguments.claim: The deceased's title as trustee was a personal right with no monetary value, conferring no rights but only duties, and thus not property for estate duty

anchor.surface_text: The deceased Safiabai had only 1/3rd share in the income of the trust property. That interest undoubtedly passed on her death. In the remaining 2/3rd Income, she had no interest and the same did not pass on her death. Her title to the property as a trustee was purely a personal right. It had no value in terms of money. It conferred no right on her. It only imposed some duties. Such a right cannot be Considered as property.

arguments.claim: Only the beneficial interest that changed on death passes, analogous to Re Thomas Townsend where only specific shares and annuity cessor were dutiable

anchor.surface_text: The meaning of the expression property passing on the death of the deceased found in the corresponding English Act was considered by the Kings Bench in Re Thomas Townsend, Deceased 1 . In that case a testator who died before the commencement of the Finance Act, 1894, by his will, bequeathed his real and personal estate to trustees for sale and investment, and for payment out of the annual income thereof of an annuity to his wife, and, subject to the annuity, to his eight children equally,-and after the death of his wife to divide the trust fund among the children in equal shares but if the fund exceeded a certain specified sum, then to divide eight-ninths of such excess among the children, and to pay the remaining ninth to certain other persons.

arguments.claim: In Mahendra Rambhai Patel, property passed where there was change in beneficial interest despite no delivery of shares; confirms focus on beneficial interest
Under s.5, only the beneficial interest of the deceased in the trust estate passed on her death; entire trust estate did not pass; legal title change immaterial

anchor.surface_text: The High Court opined that under s. 5 of the Act only the beneficial interest of the deceased in the trust estate passed on her death. It rejected the contention of the Department that the entire trust estate passed on her death.

anchor.surface_text: The accountable person objected to the inclusion of the value of the 1/3rd share in the trust properties in the computation of the value of the estate that passed on the death of Safiabai.

arguments.court_reasoning: 1/3rd beneficial income interest did pass on death

holdings.text: Only 1/3rd interest in the trust property passed on her death as that was the deceased's beneficial interest in the income.

anchor.surface_text: From the facts mentioned earlier, it is seen that ever since the death of the settlor, beneficial interest in 2/3rd of the income of the trust property vested on persons other than the deceased. The deceased was entitled only to on 1/3rd share in the income of the trust property. In substance, only 1/3rd interest in the trust property passed on her death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Beneficial interest test applied to trust deed terms: deceased entitled only to 1/3rd income post-settlor's death; 2/3rd vested in others earlier; no change in beneficial enjoyment for remainder.

holdings.text: The deceased had only 1/3rd share in the income of the trust property which passed on her death; she had no interest in the remaining 2/3rd income which did not pass.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of trust deed provisions to deceased's entitlements post-settlor's death.

holdings.text: Her title to the property as a trustee was purely a personal right with no value in terms of money; it conferred no right but only imposed duties and thus cannot be considered as property passing on death.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Trustee holds legal title for benefit of others; lacks beneficial enjoyment or monetary value; duty not property under s.5 and s.2(15).

holdings.text: The expression 'property passing on the death' means a change in beneficial interests by comparing persons beneficially interested before and after death; not mere change in legal title.

anchor.surface_text: The expression property passing on death is not a technical expression. In other words, it is not a term of law, The word passes means changes hands. To ascertain whether property has passed, a comparison must be made between the persons beneficially interested the moment before the death and the persons so interested the moment after the death

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive s.2(16) does not exhaust meaning; follows Lord Russell in Scott v. IRC and Greens Death Duties; substance over form.

holdings.text: If beneficial enjoyment of property is unaffected by death in substance, it does not pass merely due to terminological change in limitations.

anchor.surface_text: If. after much a comparison, it appears that the beneficial enjoyment of the property  a definable part thereof  was, in substance and in events, unaffected by the death, the property  or that part thereof  did not pass on the death merely because, as a matter of terminology, one set of limitations then ceased to have effect and another became operatives.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cited from Greens Death Duties; no duty where no de facto change in beneficial enjoyment despite title shifts.

holdings.text: What is relevant in determining whether property passed on death is the change in beneficial interest, not title.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to Re Thomas Townsend: only parts where beneficial interest changed were dutiable.

holdings.text: Section 2(16) is only an inclusive definition and does not fully bring out the meaning of 'property passing on the death'.

anchor.surface_text: This definition is only an inclusive definition. It does not bring out the meaning of the expression property passing on the death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis: requires substantive interpretation via beneficial interest test.

It is further observed therein to the extent that there is numberchange or bene- ficial enjoyment de facto, property does number pass merely because the exact nature or extent of the beneficial inte-  1  1937 A. precedents.case_name: Scott and Coutts and Co. v. Inland Revenue Commissioner
precedents.cited_proposition: To ascertain whether property has passed, a comparison must be made between the persons beneficially interested the moment before the death and the persons so interested the moment after the death

anchor.surface_text: The meaning of the expression property passing on the death of the deceased found in the companyresponding English Act was companysidered by the Kings Bench in Re Thomas Townsend, Deceased 1 . In that case a testator who died before the companymencement of the Finance Act, 1894, by his will, bequeathed his real and personal estate to trustees for sale and investment, and for payment out of the annual income thereof of an annuity to his wife, and, subject to the annuity, to his eight children equally,-and after the death of his wife to divide the trust fund among the children in equal shares but if the fund exceeded a certain specified sum, then to divide eight-ninths of such excess among the children, and to pay the remaining ninth to certain other persons. The wife died after the Finance Act, 1894, had companye into operation. The Court held that the estate duty was only payable on the one-ninth share of the excess of the trust fund over the specified sum and on the benefit which accrued to the children by the cessor of the annuity, since that was the only property passing on the death of the wife. Dealing with the question of law arising for decision Kennedy J. observed There is numberquestion that, looking to the substance of the disposition which is in question, as to 9600 pond the children took an interest on the death of testator which was 1901 2 K.B. 331. qua that sum a definite ascertained profit which vested in them

precedents.cited_proposition: Estate duty is payable only on the property where beneficial enjoyment changes on death; vested interests prior to death do not pass on the subsequent death
precedents.cited_holding: the estate duty was only payable on the one-ninth share of the excess of the trust fund over the specified sum and on the benefit which accrued to the children by the cessor of the annuity, since that was the only property passing on the death of the wife

precedents.citation: Mahendra Rambhai Patel v. Controller of Estate Duty, Gujarat 1 63 I.T.R. 645

anchor.surface_text: This companyclusion of ours receives support-from the decision of this Court in Mahendra Rambhai Patel v. Controller of Estate Duty, Gujarat 1 . Therein by a deed of trust dated June 28, 1941 one Ramibhai settled 160 fully paid up shares in a companypany in trust for the benefit of his son Manubhai and Mahendra is equal shares. The trustees were to stand possessed of the shares until each of the beneficiaries companypleted the age of 25 years and apply in their discretion the whole or part of the profits arising therefrom for the maintenance and advancement of the beneficiaries and to invest the surplus. If and when each of the beneficiaries companypleted the age of 25 years the trustees were to transfer out of the 160 shares his portion of the shares and the accumulation or any other investment in lieu thereof to him absolutely. If any of the beneficiaries should die before companypleting the age of 25 years, the shares settled on him  but number the accumulated surplus income  were to devolve on certain persons. The beneficiaries had numberright to mortgage or create any encumbrance or sell it until each of them companypleted the age of 25  1  63 I.T.R. 645 years. Manubhai died on June 7, 1954, a minor and unmarried and the principal value of his interest in the settled property was brought to estate duty in the hands of his brother.

precedents.case_name: Mahendra Rambhai Patel v. Controller of Estate Duty, Gujarat
precedents.cited_proposition: in determining whether a particular property passed on the death of a deceased what has to be seen is whether that deceased had any beneficial interest in that property and whether that interest passed to someone on his death
precedents.cited_holding: The interest of Manubhai in the shares and in the accumulated income was property within the meaning of section 2(15). That property did, as we have already pointed out, vest in ownership in Manubhai immediately on the execution of the deed of trust. On Manubhai dying unmarried, the property as to the shares under clause 7 of the deed and as to the accumulated income under the law of inheritance devolved on his brother Mahender. On Manubhais death, there was under the deed of trust a change in the person who was, beneficially interested in the shares.

anchor.surface_text: From the facts mentioned earlier, it is seen that ever since the death of the settlor, beneficial interest in 2/3rd of the income of the trust property vested on persons other than the deceased. The deceased was entitled only to on 1/3rd share in the income of the trust property. In substance, only 1/3rd interest in the trust property passed on her death.

outcome.relief_summary: Only 1/3rd interest in the trust property passed on the death of the deceased Bai Safiabai; the trustee title does not constitute property passing on death.

anchor.surface_text: The expression property passing on death is not a technical expression. In other words, it is not a term of law, The word passes means changes hands. To ascertain whether property has passed, a comparison must be made between the persons beneficially interested the moment before the death and the persons so interested the moment after the death
